Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AVATOL - Next Generation Phenomics for the Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Darwin's theory of evolution explained that millions of species are related, and dealt biologists and paleontologists the enormous challenge of discovering the branching pattern of the Tree of Life. Work on this great challenge is producing a map of species-relatedness through Earth history, and answering questions such as "what is the closest relative of a species?" and "what species make important products?" To do this scientists draw on all heritable features, including genotypes (e.g., DNA) and phenotypes (e.g., anatomy). Studying phenotypes, however, has remained complicated and slow, because it has not been revolutionized by computer science and engineering innovations.

A team of biologists, computer scientists, and paleontologists will extend and adapt methods from computer vision, machine learning, crowd-sourcing and natural language processing to enable rapid and automated study of phenotypes for the Tree of Life on a vast scale. The three-year goal is to release large phenomic datasets built using new methods, and to provide the public and scientific community with tools for future work. Planned is the training of teachers and students (kindergarten - postdoctoral levels) and the engagement of "citizen scien-tists." Enormous phenomic datasets, many with images, will fill an important public interest in biodiversity and the fossil record.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Next Generation Phenomics for the Tree of Life - Plant Data Team

The plant data providers at the New York Botanical Garden were part of a team of biologists, paleontologists, computer scientists, and software developers who took up the challenge of adapting modern computer science and engineering innovations to the collection of phenomic data. Phenomics is the study of phenotypes – the observable characters of organisms such as their physical and behavioral characters – in other words, everything but their genes. While collecting gene sequence data has become cheap and fast, collecting phenotype data remains a slow, expensive, and largely manual process. Nonetheless, phenotype data are of critical importance for building large-scale representations of evolutionary relationships, known as phylogenetic trees.

The Next Generation Phenomics project advanced existing methods in Computer Vision (automated extraction of information from images), Natural Language Processing (automated extraction of information from text), and Crowd Sourcing (web-based methods that allow anyone to contribute to data collection) to build researcher-friendly software to help speed up the collection of phenotype data. The role of the plant data team was to serve as a real world test case for software developers, to keep tool building targeted and relevant. The plant data team assembled over 800 images of leaves and flowers for over 250 species of the Liliales (the order containing Lilies and their close relatives) and defined 57 characters that have to do with leaf shape, leaf vein patterns, flower shape, and flower color. All images and characters are stored on Morphobank (http://morphobank.org/index.php) and on the Bisque platform at CyVerse (http://bisque.iplantcollaborative.org/) and are being made publicly available as publications are completed.

Using the plant and other images, workflows for extracting phenotypic data from images were created using Crowd Sourcing and Computer Vision methods. The Crowd Sourcing tools allow scientist to prepare a set of images and characters using Morphobank and then make them available to different crowds (e.g., students or the general public) using the interface at http://www.theevolutionproject.org/. This is the first publicly available tool to crowd source the collection of phenotypic data for phylogenetic tree building. The Computer Vision tools use the desktop program AvatolC, in which scientist answers a series of questions about image quality and characters definitions, the answers dictating which of three newly developed Computer Vision algorithms to use.  The software then retrieves the images from MorphoBank or Bisque, trains the algorithm, and generates character data. Unlike much of current Computer Vision research, these algorithms are able to generalize to new images showing previously-unseen species, using small (sometimes less than 10) sets of training images.

Phenomics is critical not only for building the Tree of Life on earth, but also for understanding how organisms function and survive, respond to diseases or environmental challenges, and interact with other organisms. Moreover, Phenomics is the only source of data for fossils that allow us to understand where and when germane features arose in the history of life on earth. By advancing methods for generating phenotypic data more efficiently, the Next Generation Phenomics project and the plant data team have made a fundamental contribution to biological research.
